dc:dc.dc:title: Staff Members of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 7 x 5 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 86.

Handwritten on envelope: ''#369 Clarence Darrow at JCRS''. On back of photograph: ''#369 L to R Dr. Isadore Bronfin. Staff members of Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society with Judge Ben Lindsey of Denver Juvenile Court and Clarence Darrow 1926 L to R: Dr. Isadore Bronfin, Judge Ben Lindsey, Dr. Leo Tepley, Clarence Darrow, Dr. Charles Spivak, Courtesy Ira M. Beck Memorial Archives Rocky Mountain Jewish Historical Society Center for Judaic Studies University of Denver.''

Left to right: Dr. Isidor Bronfin, JCRS medical superintendent and tuberculosis specialist; Denver Judge Ben Lindsey of the juvenile court; Dr. Leo Tepley, JCRS physician; Clarence Darrow, Scopes trial lawyer; and Dr. Charles Spivak, physician and founder of the JCRS. The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. The sanatorium was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver.
Donated by AMC Cancer Research Center (JCRS).
ph369

dc:dc.dc:title: Rabbi Manuel Laderman at Union Station
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 8.5 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Copy of photograph is missing and a reprint was made.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 68.

Twenty-three-year-old Rabbi Manuel Laderman (tallest man in the group) surrounded by delegates from the Hebrew Educational Alliance upon his arrival at Union Station, Denver, Colorado in 1932. He graduated from the Hebrew Theological College in Illinois and had just been ordained when he came to Denver to serve as the first Rabbi of the Hebrew Educational Alliance. He served as rabbi at the Orthodox synagogue until 1979. He was born August 25, 1909 and died in Denver on November 27, 1989.
Copy of the photograph was donated for the Rocky Mountain Jewish Historical Society Annual Meeting in 2000.

dc:dc.dc:title: Opening of Dave Cook Sporting Goods Store, Denver, Colo.
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 8 x 10 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Appears in, ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' By Dr. Jeanne Abrams on page 55.

On envelope: "#1034 Cooks Sporting Goods." Handwritten on back of photograph: "Opening of Dave Cook Sporting Goods, 1601 Larimer St store, 1936, Standing from left to right: Nate Bernstone, Dave Cook, Jane Cook, Herb Cook, Belle Smernoff."

The staff of Dave Cook Sporting Goods stand in front of the counter next to baskets of flowers, celebrating the grand opening of the store at 1601 Larimer Street, Denver, Colorado. In 1924, Dave and Max Cook went into the sporting goods business, operating the first major sports store in Colorado.
Donated by Leonard Gordan.

dc:dc.dc:title: Ben Glass with H. Leivick, Yiddish Poet
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 7.5 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title from back of photograph.
Photograph dimensions include matting shown in photograph.

On front of matting: ''Cavarra Studio, Denver'' and handwritten Yiddish words and ''1933.'' Handwritten on back of photograph: ''Ben Glass with H. Leivick, Yiddish poet, 1933. Patients of JCRS. Donor: Mr. and Mrs. Ben Glass.

Portrait of Ben Glass (at left) and H. Leivick (the pen name of Leyṿiḳ Halpern or Leivick Halper), Yiddish poet. Both men were patients at the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS). Ben Glass was a printer at the JCRS bindery from 1928 to 1978 when it closed. The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish working men along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. It was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver. This is a copy of the original photograph and matting.
Donated by Ben and Bessie Glass.

Postcard markings stamped on back of photograph. Handwritten on back of photograph: ''Seven Falls, Colo. June 1910, Family of Moritz Bernstein of Walsenberg [sic], Donor Morton P. Stark.'' On envelope: ''Bernstein family of Walsenberg[sic] at Seven Falls, 1910.''

dc:dc.dc:title: Portrait of Philip Hornbein Reading
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 8 x 10 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Framed copy of this photograph in collection B167.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, on page 22.
On back of photograph: ''#135 Marjorie Hornbein 1124 Steele Denver, CO 80206 1938 Philip Hornbein Donated by Miss Marjorie Hornbein''. On envelope: ''#135 Phillip Hornbein, 1938''.

Philip Hornbein is reading in a chair with a cigarette in his hand. Hornbein was one of Colorado's top trial lawyers, a leader in the fight against the Ku Klux Klan, and chairman of Colorado's Democratic Party during the presidency of Franklin D. Roosevelt. He graduated from the University of Denver School of Law, practiced in Cripple Creek, then Denver, Colorado.
Donated by Miss. Marjorie Hornbein.

dc:dc.dc:title: Major Operating Room at the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 8 x 10 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Inked on negative: ''Mile High Photo, 20135.'' Handwritten on envelope: ''#452 JCRS Misc. Medical Facilities.'' On back of photograph: ''#452 JCRS Major operating room for collapsing lungs.''

Interior of the major operating room used for collapsed lungs on the campus of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS). The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. The sanatorium was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver.
Accession # 1271, Donated by AMC Cancer Research Center as part of the JCRS Records.

dc:dc.dc:title: Jacob and Charlotte Gordon and their Daughters
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 7 x 5 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 106.

Jacob and Charlotte Gordon stand in front of a building. In front of them are their daughters, Bess (with a large bow), Baila, and Eleanor. A son born later is not shown in the photograph. Jacob, a schohet (a kosher slaughterer in the Jewish tradition), Talmudic scholar, and later a mohel (one who performs the ritual circumcision), migrated to Denver, Colorado, in 1914 from Russia to join his uncle, Velvel Heller. By 1917 Jacob Gordon saved enough to bring his wife and daughter Bess from Russia and the family settled on Denver's west side. Two more daughters and a son were born in Denver. Charlotte Gordon was a founder of the Beth David Sisterhood, which was organized for the purpose of building a school for Jewish education on Denver's west side. As treasurer she collected dimes and quarters for the school in the neighborhoods on the west side of Denver. The Sisterhood merged with the Denver Hebrew Institute and became the Hebrew Educational Alliance.
A copy was donated for an article by Marjorie Hornbein in the Rocky Mountain Jewish Historical Notes, Volume 4, Number 3, Spring 1982.
Photo Book #157.

dc:dc.dc:title: Geriatric Center at Beth Israel Hospital
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 7 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 90.
Handwritten on envelope: ''#543 Beth Israel Home.'' On back of photograph: ''#543 Old Folks Home Beth Israel Hospital.''

Exterior view of the Geriatric Center at Beth Israel Hospital in Denver, Colorado at the corner of Sixteenth Avenue and Lowell Boulevard. Beth Israel opened in Denver's west-side community in 1920 as a Jewish old-age home. It added a Jewish-run general hospital in 1923. Sparked by Bella Mintz, it garnered the support of members of Denver's Jewish community from throughout the city. Philanthropists Leopold Guldman, Isadore Rude, and Adolph Kiesler provided especially generous donations. Eventually its geriatric center evolved into Denver's Shalom Park, located today in Aurora, Colorado.
Donated by Beth Israel Hospital and Geriatric Center.

Hannah Levy sits in an outdoor setting in the early 1930s. Hannah and brother Jack Levy are the founders of several women's clothing retail stores, in Colorado: the Hosiery Bar, Fashion Bar, and Hannah. dc:dc.dc:title: Portrait of the Louis Anfenger Family
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 8 x 10 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, on page 20.
On back of photograph: ''#37 Family of Louis Anfenger Donor Marjorie Hornbein''. On envelope: ''#37 Louis Anfenger and Louis Anfenger family, c 1890s''.

Louis (1842-1900) and Louise Schlesinger (1847-1938) Anfenger seated front center, with their eight children. Children, back row, left to right: Max, Fannie, Stella, Milton, and Fred. Children front row: Harold, Flora, and Joseph. Louis Anfenger was born in Bavaria and came to the United States in the 1850s. He moved west to Denver, Colorado in 1870, started out working as a clerk, and became a highly successful businessman in the area of real estate. Louise He was also elected to the state legislature in the 1880s. Anfenger built a stately house at Champa Street and Twenty-Ninth Street for his wife Louise and their large family.
Donated by Marjorie Hornbein.

dc:dc.dc:title: Art Class at the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 4 x 7 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Handwritten on envelope: ''#462 JCRS Patient Activities''. On back of photograph: ''#462 JCRS Art Class - 1942''.

An art class that is part of the rehabilitation program of the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society (JCRS) meets for a session. Male patients sit on folding chairs in a half circle around a male model wearing a robe, pajamas, slippers and hat. Max Lazarus, a German-Jewish artist, is pictured second from the left. Twenty-three charcoal drawings hang on the walls. The JCRS was a sanatorium for tuberculosis patients that was founded in 1904 by a group of immigrant Jewish workingmen along with the support of several leading physicians and rabbis in Denver, Colorado. It was located on West Colfax Avenue just outside of Denver.
Donated by AMC Cancer Research Center (JCRS).

dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 8 x 10 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.

Exterior shot features a sign over the top front porch, which reads, "The Frances Jacobs Hospital". The name was changed to National Jewish Hospital in 1899. Two men (unidentified) stand in front of the building. In 1907, the name of the hospital changed to the National Asthma Center. dc:dc.dc:title: Interior View of the Star Bakery
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 9 x 6 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 40.

Printed on the page below the photograph: "Star Bakery, 2744 W. Colfax in Denver, was founded by Eva and Jacob Boscowitz in 1907., Pictured left to right: Rudy Boscowitz (Boscoe), Elya Rubin, Eva Boscowitz Rubin, Sam Boscowitz (Boscoe), Courtesy: Jay Boscoe, Sponsors: Mr. and Mrs. Jay Boscoe, Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph Boscoe."

Members of the Boscowitz and Rubin families stand in the Star Bakery store surrounded by loaves of bread. Pictured from left to right are Rudy Boscowitz (Boscoe), Elya (Eli) Rubin, Eva Boscowitz Rubin and Sam Boscowitz (Boscoe). Located at 2744 West Colfax in Denver, Colorado, the Star Bread Company (operating as Star Bakery) was founded by East European immigrants Eva and Jacob Boscowitz in 1907. After her husband's death in 1909, Eva Boscowitz continued to operate the store, later marrying another baker, Elya (Eli) Rubin. The boys changed their names to Rudy Boscoe and Sam Boscoe, eventually taking over and operating the business until the 1970s.
Copy donated by Jay Boscoe for ''A Colorado Jewish Family Album.''

dc:dc.dc:title: Seraphine Pisko
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 7 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title from back of photograph.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 77.
Handwritten on envelope: ''#84 Mrs. Seraphine Pisko at NJH.'' On back of photograph: ''#84 Seraphine Pisko.''

Seraphine Eppstein Pisko sits at a desk at National Jewish Hospital (NJH). She served as the president of the Hebrew Ladies' Benevolent Society (renamed the Jewish Relief Society in 1901) and as president of the Denver Council of Jewish Women. She also helped organize the Denver Jewish Settlement House and a free kindergarten to benefit the Eastern European Jewish immigrants on Denver's west side. Pisko became a fund-raiser for the National Jewish Hospital for Consumptives, and in 1911 she was appointed secretary of NJH and later was named executive director as well as vice president. She was in administrative control of the day-to-day activities until her retirement in 1938.
Donated by National Jewish Hospital.

dc:dc.dc:title: Portrait of Anna Ginsberg Hayutin
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 5 x 4 inches., black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Pictured in ''Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 99.
On back of photograph: ''#465 Anna F. Hayutin 1912? (Mrs. Morris Hayutin)''. On envelope: ''#465 Hayutin Family''.

Anna Ginsberg Hayutin sits with her hands folded on her lap. She wears an elaborate hat and a long dress with lace at the collar and sleeves. Anna Ginsberg was born in Russia but came to New York City with her parents, D'vera and Max Ginsberg. They moved to Denver in 1910 when she was still a young girl. Anna married the son of Russian immigrants, businessman Morris Hayutin, who owned the Western Supply Company and later the Public Industrial Bank.
Donated by Peryle Hayutin Beck.

dc:dc.dc:title: Children in Front of the Jewish Sheltering Home in Denver
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 8 x 11 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.

A group of children gather in front of the original Denver Sheltering Home at 19th Street and Julian Street in Denver, Colorado. A man and the matron stand on either side of the children. The Sheltering Home began as a home for the children of tuberculosis patients who came to the sanatoriums in Denver. The Denver Sheltering Home later became the National Asthma Center. The original building was destroyed by fire in 1914. The 36 children living in the home at the time were taken in by neighborhood families until a new building could be erected.
Donated by AMC Cancer Research Center (JCRS).

dc:dc.dc:title: Cripple Creek Jewish Community Members
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 114.

On back of photograph: ''Sarah Sticker, Mrs. Gus Mautner, Mrs. L. Cohen, Mrs. Rosenberg, Mrs. Max Guldman, Clara Kolm, Dick Cohen, Paula Heller, Anna Segal, Regina Roth, Sadie Levy, May Garrett, Gertie Garrett, Mrs. L. Koretz, Sadie Schradsky, Nathan Segal, Ellis Rosenberg, Louis Koretz, Max Guldman, Morris Cohen, Harry Harris, Joe Cohen, Gus Mautner, Sol Segal, [illegible] Garrett, L. Silverman, L. Caro, S. Rudman; Return: Miriam Goldberg, 915 Monaco Pkwy, Denver, CO 80220; 861-2234; 377-0350; #990.'' On envelope: ''#990 Young Jewish Community of Cripple Creek, Co c. 1900.''

A group of early Jewish residents of Cripple Creek, Colorado, gathered for a social outing in the 1890s. The following are pictured: Sarah Sticker, Mrs. Gus Mautner, Mrs. L. Cohen, Mrs. Rosenberg, Mrs. Max Guldman, Clara Kolm, Dick Cohen, Paula Heller, Anna Segal, Regina Roth, Sadie Levy, May Garrett, Gertie Garrett, Mrs. L. Koretz, Sadie Schradsky, Nathan Segal, Ellis Rosenberg, Louis Koretz, Max Guldman, Morris Cohen, Harry Harris, Joe Cohen, Gus Mautner, Sol Segal, H. Garrett, L. Silverman, L. Caro, and S. Rudman. Cripple Creek was a thriving mining town in the 1890s with an active Jewish community. Many Jewish merchants established themselves in Cripple Creek. Jewish religious services were held regularly, and a B'nai B'rith chapter was founded in 1901. After mining petered out in the area in the early years of the 20th century, most Jews moved to Denver.
Photograph was donated by Miriam Goldberg.

dc:dc.dc:title: Collage of Cook, Battock, and Hayutin Businesses
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 14 x 11 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.

Handwritten on the back of the photograph: ''#57, Collage of Mrs. Harry Cook & Daughter of Cook's Baths. She was known as 'Dis Bakerkeh' in charge of the Mikveh.'; Mr. Harry Battock, peddler on fruit wagon; Motorcycle shop of Morris Hayutin; Donors: Mr. Louis Cook, Mrs. Mary Kreisman, Mr. Peryle H. Beck.''

The upper left photograph shows Ida Cook and her daughter standing in front of a house. Harry and Ida Cook owned the Cook's Russian Baths in Denver, Colorado. At night, the Baths served as a mikveh (ritual bath) that was operated for women by Ida Cook. During the day the Baths served as a popular steam bath open to the public, complete with catered kosher meals. The upper right photograph shows Harry Battock, who came to Denver to be treated at the Jewish Consumptives' Relief Society, and peddled fruit and vegetables from a horse-drawn wagon on Denver's west side. The bottom photograph shows Morris Hayutin behind a motorcycle, underneath a canopy. There is another motorcycle beside Morris Hayutin and several cars are parked behind the canopy. Morris Hayutin's bicycle and motorcycle business, the Western Supply Company, was located on the corner of 15th and Larimer streets in Denver.
Donated by Peryle Hayutin Beck, daughter of Morris Hayutin.
ph57

dc:dc.dc:title: Clara Goldsmith Stands in Formal Pose
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 7 x 5 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 15.
Handwritten on envelope: ''Goldsmith, Clara (Weil) (sic), born Denver 1860.''

Clara Goldsmith Weil stands behind a fence prop for a formal portrait. Clara, born in 1860, was the first female Jewish baby born in Denver. Clara's parents, Clara and Henry Goldsmith, had migrated by covered wagon from Leavenworth, Kansas. The elder Clara died in childbirth and her daugher was named after her mother. Clara Goldsmith Weil was raised by her aunt and uncle Rosa and Abraham Goldsmith. The elder Clara Goldsmith's death was the impetus behind the organization of Denver's first Jewish burial society.
Donated by Dorothy Shipman.

Handwritten on envelope: ''#136 Fannie Lorber at Sheltering Home.'' On back of photograph: ''#136 Fannie Lorber Breaking Ground at the Sheltering Home 1937?''

Mrs. Fannie E. Lorber was one of the founders of the Denver Sheltering Home, which opened in 1908. She is shoveling dirt for a groundbreaking of the Lorber Building, with many men and women looking on. The Sheltering Home began as a home for the children of tubercular patients who came to the sanitoriums in Denver, Colo.

Max Stein arrived in Pueblo in 1898 (he is the man on the right) after serving as a mounted policeman, he began peddling fruit and vegetables from a wagon. About 1910 he opened a retail grocery store at 1156 4th St., Pueblo. The business is still in the same location but has expanded to become a wholesale food company. Marvin Stein, the present owner, is a third-generation Stein.'' On back of photograph: ''Albert Stein's Royal Liquors 117 E. 4th St. (first liquor store in Pueblo after prohibition was abolished) c 1932 Donor Mrs. Ruth Stein #386.''

Interior of Royal Liquors in Pueblo, Colorado. The store was located at 117 E. 4th Street and was the first liquor store in Pueblo after prohibition was abolished. The store was owned by Albert Stein.

dc:dc.dc:title: Maurice Epstein Cartoon
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item photograph, 10 x 8 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
On envelope: "#1049 Maurice Epstein." Caption on image: "Cartoon published in the Denver Post. Sunday, December 30, 1923."

Cartoon of Maurice Epstein with a photograph head and cartoon body. He holds three caps and around him are more drawn pictures and writing. Counter clockwise from the top, ''Maurice likes to burn up the roads in his big Lincoln.'' On a billboard near a car, ''Imperial Caps 'Just a mile above the rest of 'em.''' On a sign, ''This is Mr. Epstein owner of Midwest Cap Wrks. Biggest cap factory west of Chicago!!'' Near a factory, ''''Imperial' Midwest Caps going to important centers.'' Trains traveling to San Fransisco, Los Angeles, and New Orleans. Finally, a man is walking away saying, ''Mine is a Midwest cap!''

dc:dc.dc:title: Morris Hayutin Family at Balanced Rock, Colorado Springs
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 10 x 8 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, on page 98.
''Morris Hayutin Family at Manitou Springs, c. 1914.''

Morris and Anna (Ginsberg) Hayutin siting in the front seat in the car, Soloman Hayutin is the other man in the car, and Devera and Max Ginsberg sit on the back seat. The car is parked in front of the Balanced Rock in Garden of the Gods, Colorado Springs, Colorado. Morris Hayutin's niece, Freda Hayutin (child) is also seated in the car. Members of the Hayutin family arrived in Denver in the 1890s.
Donated by Peryle Hayutin Beck.

dc:dc.dc:title: Max Stein and his Produce Wagon
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 4 x 5 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.

Handwritten on envelope: ''# 386 Stein family of Pueblo, 1900-1960 info inside.'' Photocopy of handwritten note inside original envelope: ''Taken in Pueblo, Colorado between 1913 and 1914. Max Stein arrived in Pueblo in 1898 (he is the man on the right) after serving as a mounted policeman, he began peddling fruit and vegetables from a wagon. About 1910 he opened a retail grocery store at 1156 4th St., Pueblo. The business is still in the same location but has expanded to become a wholesale food company. Marvin Stein, the present owner, is a third-generation Stein.'' On back of photograph: ''Max Stein c. 1910 Pueblo Co. Donor Mrs. Ruth Stein #386.''
Max Stein seated on the driver's seat of his produce wagon, which is being driven by two horses. The wagon is in front of a building with a small crowd of unidentified people standing on the porch.
Donated by Mrs. Ruth Stein

dc:dc.dc:title: Montage of Elias Cohen and Family of Aspen, Colorado
dc:dc.dc:format: 1 item (photograph), 10 x 8 inches, black and white
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, on page 120.

On envelope: ''Elias Cohen family of Aspen, 1905''. Note inside envelope: ''#52 Elias Cohen family - supervisor of mines in Aspen in Aspen, with his wife and children and his wife's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Weinberg Aspen 1905 (Mrs. Elias Cohen, nee Weinberg) donated by Mrs. Regina Collins''.

Collage of the Elias Cohen family of Aspen including a formal portrait of Elias Cohen (bottom left); a formal portrait of his wife and two daughters (bottom right); and formal portraits of his in-laws, Mr. and Mrs. Charles Weinberg (top). Elias Cohen was a resident of Aspen by 1891, a mine supervisor in, and manager of David Hyman's properties. It was Cohen who suggested the use of deep-sea divers to repair broken mine-pump shafts.
Donated by Mrs. Regina Collins

dc:dc.dc:title: Interior of Isaacs' Hardware Store in Leadville
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.

Newspaper article with the photo titled ''Leadville Woman has Oldest Range in Rocky Mountains'' (undated) states that two individuals, Eva Zelezniker and Joe Matekal, owned the two oldest working Monarch coal ranges in the Rocky Mountain region. Monarch gave her a new electric range and him an electric griddle. The coal ranges had been purchased in Hyman Isaacs store in the early 1900s and had been advertised by Isaacs in the Herald Democrat as the ''Stay Satisfactory'' range.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 117.

Handwritten on envelope: "167 Isaac's Hardware Store, Leadville, c 1909." Handwritten on back of photograph: "#167, Hyman Isaac's Hardware Store in Leadville btn 4th and 5th (420?) Harrison Ave. c. 1909, See Leadville file for description."
Interior view of Hyman Isaacs' Hardware Store in Leadville, Colorado. There is an unidentified man in the center of the photograph who is leaning against a counter.

dc:dc.dc:title: Bronze Statue of Frances Wisebart Jacobs
dc:dc.dc:description: Title supplied by archivist.
Appears in ''Images of America: Jewish Denver 1859-1940,'' by Dr. Jeanne Abrams, page 75.
On envelope: ''#818 Frances Jacobs Statue''.

Bronze statue is an artist's rendering of Frances Wisebart Jacobs holding her bag of soaps and medicines. The plaque affixed to the base of statue explains Jacob's ties with National Jewish Hospital, which was founded in her memory. The statue is located in the National Jewish Center, Denver, Colo.
Photograph was donated by National Jewish Hospital.
